content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The continuous function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma 5, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> consists of a parabola and two line segments, as shown in the figure above. Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function such that <math alttext="g prime of x, equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Fill in the missing entries in the table below to describe the behavior of <math alttext="f prime "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f double prime"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Indicate Positive, Negative, or 0. Give reasons for your answers.

<math alttext="The figure presents a partially completed 4 row table, with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “f double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. Negative 5 is less than x, is less than negative 3. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 2. Negative 3 is less than x, is less than negative 1. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 3. Negative 1 is less than x, is less than 2. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 4. 2 is less than x, is less than 5. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. "><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="4em 0.05em 6em 6em 6em 6em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

The continuous function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma 5, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> consists of a parabola and two line segments, as shown in the figure above. Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a function such that <math alttext="g prime of x, equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Fill in the missing entries in the table below to describe the behavior of <math alttext="f prime "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="f double prime"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Indicate Positive, Negative, or 0. Give reasons for your answers.

<math alttext="The figure presents a partially completed 4 row table, with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The heading for row 3 is “f prime of x.” The heading for row 4 is “f double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. Negative 5 is less than x, is less than negative 3. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 2. Negative 3 is less than x, is less than negative 1. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 3. Negative 1 is less than x, is less than 2. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. Column 4. 2 is less than x, is less than 5. f of x is Positive. f prime of x is a blank cell. f double prime of x is a blank cell. "><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="4em 0.05em 6em 6em 6em 6em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b)   There is no value of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the open interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, negative 1 comma 5, close parenthesis "><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at which <math alttext="f prime of x, equals, the fraction with numerator f of 5, minus, f of negative 1, and denominator 5 minus negative 1, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain why this does not violate the Mean Value Theorem.

(c)   Find all values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the open interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, negative 5 comma 5, close parenthesis "><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> at which the graph of <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a point of inflection. Explain your reasoning.

(d)   At what value of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> does <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> attain its absolute maximum on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, negative 5 comma 5, close bracket"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
